comments.commentBody:
Settlements are a joke. They allow the perps to walk free and they fail to create any new case law which might give prosecutors the legal footing on which to base future cases. And, of course, they are pathetically small, compared to the profits of these behemoth enterprises.

The "significant prices" Barclays may be paying is a pittance -- and it is clear that no individuals will be held accountable or will spend a minute in jaul. Not so the lone pot dealer in Camden who gets caught with a dime bag.

Justice is for the rich and the connected and, the evil.

Have you ever read your loan agreements? If you did, you might see that it very clearly specifies something like Fed Rate + 3%.

Nothing fishy at all. If you don't like the loan terms, find an alternate financing source.

All this hoopla and outrage over rigging the LiBor 5 , 10, or 30 basis points is really missing the elephant in the room.  

The "Prime Rate" is really much more relevant to the U.S.  during the past 50 years.  Until more recently the Libor is not even in the picture in U.S. consumer credit. Most credit cards and consumer loans are/were more tied to the "prime rate" which was defined as the "the rate the banks charged to the banks' most credit worthy customers, such as the AAA companies".  Since the late 1980's the banks have been systematically rigging the prime rate by gradually increasing it over time so that it is now almost 300 basis points (3%) over the real "prime rate", i.e., what the banks really charged AAA companies such as Exxon and Johnson and Johnson.  This is the banks way of picking everyone's pocket without permission to the extend of billions and billions of dollars every year.  It is the biggest fraud in America.

Our government and the Federal Reserve actually are part of this scheme in that they redefined the definition of "Prime Rate" in the official publications rather than stopping the banks from doing this. You can check this out just by looking at the old publications from the Federal Reserve Interest Rate Series vs. the current ones.

Even attempts to correct this thru the legal system has been unsuccessful as the banks seem to have influence over the courts also (see Lum vs. Bank of America, et al).

This is not one of those settlements. Not only did Barclays have to admit blame in the settlement with the CFTC they also had to agree that neither the company or any of their agents or employees "shall take any action or make any public statement denying, directly or indirectly, any findings or conclusions in this Order or creating, or tending to create, the impression that this Order is without a factual basis ...". They also had to agree to a complete set of rules regulating their future LIBOR submissions and audits for the next five years to make sure they are being followed. The settlement did not waive criminal action against Barclays or any of its employees. Quite the opposite, Barclays waived "any claims of Double Jeopardy based on the institution of this proceeding or the entry in this proceeding of any order imposing a civil monetary penalty or any other relief".

They paid a $200 million civil monetary penalty in the U.S and $450 million in total which is about 5% of their 2011 worldwide pretax profits, 18.25 days instead of 8 minutes.

The shares of Barclays, like the shares of all major banks, have been hit extremely hard since they peaked in 2007. In Barclays case they have lost 83.6% of their value.

Don't get upset yet. This is only the tip of the iceberg.

The whole creditor versus debtor debacle has still to be settled, and we still don't know who fooled whom yet.

There has never been a crisis this great that did not involve war as part of its resolution.

Citibank sold a package of toxic mortgage-backed securities to unsuspecting customers — securities that it knew were likely to go bust — and, with the other hand, shorted the same securities. This instance had a paper trail that made the S.E.C. case winnable. Citigroup was fined $285Million in April 2012 for this but without admitting wrongdoing!
The U.S. District Court judge overseeing the case demanded that the S.E.C. explain how such serious securities fraud could end with the defendant neither admitting nor denying wrongdoing. The S.E.C claimed they were out-gunned by the banks powerful law firms and would be no match for them in a case that would drag on for many years.
Yet another example of the unjust society that has created Occupy and a general feeling that our capitalist system is rigged in favor of the 1% at the expense of the 99%.

Those "settlements" (nudge-nudge-wink-wink) where no one admits to any blame, and the "fine" is eight minutes of income, are pathetic.

What needs to happen is an admission of guilt, and 25% of a years' gross earnings as the fine, else full criminal prosecution will ensue, with the big people at the top going to prison if found guilty.

We need to hit shareholder profit and stock price hard enough that the shareholders demand honest dealings to protect their investments; toothless fines and no prosecution of individuals is an engraved invitation for the thieves to do it again.

The underlying problem is that a Right to Privacy is not yet fully a part of the law. It is half way to established, and not truly respected. It was created as a "penumbra" vaguely assigned to other rights, as a right to be left alone.

We need, first and foremost, a firmly declared Right to Privacy, enforced to the same standard as the right to free speech. It is an essential freedom in an age which enables such government intrusion and abuse.
I totally agree!  However, problems arise when parents support to the point where their child can do no wrong or when they want to be their child's "friend" which keeps them from being a parent.
Kate -- Yes.  That is one of the hardest things about being a parent, knowing where our own line is.  Love helps.

I agree completely. That is exactly what I try to do with my three kids.

There is a balance between letting them try it, and knowing that Daddy will certainly be there if they need him. That requires getting involved enough to know, and it requires the teachers and others to know too that my kids are backed up when they need it.

They need freedom to be what they can be and want to be. They need room to learn by doing, including failing a bit, but not enough to hurt themselves.

I call it boundaries. They were tight when they were young, they are wider now, and they move as seems fit, out but sometimes in again. They prove themselves to themselves, and to me, or sometimes disappoint and need to be helped with a firmer hand.

Kids actually like boundaries. It feels safe, and supports exploring.
If you won't do business with culprit banks, then I suppose you are keeping your money in a jar in your closet... or using a credit union instead of a bank.
They're free enterprise but they don't get to fix prices. And neither do you.

"I simply won't do business with the culprit banks."
-- sorry, but you probably can't avoid doing so ... do you know the identity of all the correspondent banks your local credit union works with? The banks that finance the re-insurers that support the insurance policies you hold? If you are lucky enough to have a retirement account, invest in any mutual funds, or enough funds to trade stocks and bonds on your own, do you know which banks provide the day to day liquidity needed for those accounts -- the margin accounts that any trader has to have? Unless you have all those data, you don't know with which banks you do business.

The odds are that you can't avoid doing business with the major banks if you have any accounts at financial institutions or any retirement savings other than Social Security.

So where does that fine money go anyway?

If it goes into the government coffers instead of the victims pockets then it's just another government shakedown.

I thought banks were free enterprise that could set whatever rate they wanted?

Competition and low rates would keep them in business. This will really shock the economies and put the brakes on economic growth through bank financing.

Once again, too many cops and not enough freedom.

I simply won't do business with the culprit banks. That's justice enough.

Your post shows a profound misreading of what the President said. Your hatred of the man is obvious.

Really, when was the last time you listened to one of his interview or speech in its entirety? For you to write that he does not speak to us all reveals to me that you simply have not listened to the man. Are you someone who turns off the TV the minute you hear his voice? Is your hatred that strong?

Any leader, especially the President, must construct a strong and positive narrative, a story, about the direction we are going and why. To call it "a story" is not to say the narrative is dishonest or false.

Your narrative -- of the President "starting the fire" of division and now trying to put it out with "a story of deception" -- is a good example of a false narrative. It simply is not true.

Yes, but the characters must be true to life, consistent within themselves.  The man who stayed and helped in London is not a man who would run away.  If he is otherwise the same but acts out of character, that is not serving the story.  There are limits to what can be changed in a character without losing something that also will show in the sentences.

I second Daily Reader. A specific example would have been useful here.

Your comments sounds to me like the typical response of the Fox team. If Democrats accuse Romney of something the Fox team quickly responds, "but President Obama does it, too." That is a childish response, as you may well know if you have children.

You really think Bush was doing anything about out-of-control corporations? Or that any Republican would? This isn't a topic for "hate Obama" partisanship. This is a societal problem that we ought to be solving together instead of quarreling among ourselves over personalities.

This, indeed, is where Obama has most failed us.   Thus the absurd pursuit of Obama as some kind of European socialist is idiotic ...  and will there be any change if Obama is re-elected ?   Will things be worse if Romney gets into the White House ?   One begins to wonder !

I saw an interesting Frontline segment where Obama held an important meeting with Geitner and the major bankers and told them he was the only thing between them and the pitchforks.  A come to Jesus moment during the 2008 meltdown.  He had them ...and Geitner talked him out of doing anything substantive.  That was his moment.. He let them off and then when he called for them to show up a month later in NY, they blew him off.  Then he concentrated on health care instead of the banks, and that I believe will be his greatest failure as our President.  I don't subscribe to either party anymore since I don't think they work for anyone but the corporations.

Sorry but prosecutions of bankers and Wall St. people under the Obama administration and especially under his AG is not going to happen.  Eric Holder, Obama's AG gave financier Marc Rich a "get out of jail" free card years ago and has done nothing, I mean nothing, to prosecute the bankers involved in the biggest ripoff in history since 2008.  Obama has taken hundreds of millions from the same people in campaign donations.  The sad fact of life is that politicians of both major parties have allied with the bankers and Wall St. against the interests of the general public.  Politicians need money to run their expensive campaigns and who has more of it than the banks and bankers?  This alliance is really at the heart of the crisis in American Democracy, and Citizens United has made the situation even worse.  Obama needs to fire both Holder and Timothy Geithner (and completely revamp his economic team) if he wants to get reelected.  Don't expect much from either party with regard to the banks continuing plunder of funds.  Vote Green if you want change, Obama had his chance and did nothing!
We called it "Geography."
When you consider that these international banks have been caught repeatedly laundering money for the drug cartels, your remark about organized crime is right on the mark.
where was congress? Barney Franks is a crook in my book.

We need fines that TRIPLE with each incursion. Let's see how many crimes they can commit before the company completely disappears. Can any of the six large banks survive a judgement of $100B in damages? Let's see what that does to Tier 1 capital, profits and bonuses ...

We are not being serious about this game. The numbers are too small. If you want to make a difference, the numbers have to be ridiculous by prior standards because the CRIMES themselves are on a ridiculous scale by past standards.

The banks and the financial system are the true organized crime of of our time.  Instead of time wasting activities like closing State approved medical marijuana stores put those resources to work investigating the international banking system.  Parole the non violent drug offenders to make room for these criminals.  Violators should do at least one year of hard time and have a felony conviction on their records.  Fines should be confiscatory.  A few million dollars to a multibillion dollar enterprise is nothing.  It doesn't even affect the bonuses doled out to the criminals that run them.

Actually, Phillip, Spalding and the others are right. Your comment conveniently ignores the fact that the "small premium" is a subsidy paid for energy produced at a rate that is not competitive now and may never be competitive. And the 10% doesn't come close to covering the difference - the taxpayer picks up the rest.

It's nice that Raypierre and others can elect to pay a subsidy. In lots of places, like California, you have no choice.

As Philip notes, Spalding is seriously misinformed about how the accounting works.  The money I pay is routed to the wind-based supplier, who then commits (in a verifiable way) to putting into the grid the number of kwh I have paid for. There is every incentive for the billing agent not to allow cheating, since the money I pay doesn't reach a fossil fuel based provider, so they would be putting energy into the grid but not getting paid.  There are probably ways to game the system if the nominal renewables provider is dishonest enough, but it's not easy and can easily be head off by suitable audit protocols.

See if you can find out what radio frequencies or bands they operate on. If the signals are FM then a stronger signal would overpower the drone and it would be rendered ineffective, especially when it lands so fast.

The Miskolczi claim is published in Energy and Environment, a journal with such shoddy review standards that it hardly deserves to be called peer review. If it had made it past review at some journal where it would get serious scrutiny from scientists who know the subject, like JGR or J. Climate or any of the new open-review climate journals, somebody would probably have taken the time to publish a peer-reviewed rebuttal. But you can't expect scientists with better things to do to take time and journal space to rebut every bit of lunacy that appears in E&E. The blog discussions of the paper cited are accurate and cogent, and if you understand the physics well enough to read Miscolczi's paper, you understand it well enough to read and judge the critique on your own.

Or, you can just read my Physics Today article, "Infrared Radiation and Planetary Temperature," to see directly why the basic physics connecting increased CO2 with an increased greenhouse effect is 100% certain. Link to open access reprint at:

http://geosci.uchicago.edu/~rtp1/papers/PhysTodayRT2011.pdf

http://ecowatch.org/2012/nationwide/

So much for the no regulation crowd counting on a free market solution to pollution.

Kip, did you miss this part of Bruno's commentary.

"The story is more grim in the Caribbean, where there has been a decline of at least 50 percent (and probably more than 75 percent) of coral populations.

But the picture of coral loss is roughly the same globally. More recently, we’ve been working on the extent of overfishing and predator loss on Caribbean reefs. A healthy unfished reef is inhabited by top predators like sharks and grouper and total fish biomass is roughly 500 grams per square meter. Yet, the average reef has only 20 grams per square meter — obviously an extreme decrease in fish biomass.

So that aspect of Rogers Bradbury’s Op-Ed in today’s New York Times is generally accurate. The world’s coral reefs have indeed changed, are under enormous pressure, and their future is threatened."

So this scientist of the first order seems closer in agreement with Bradbury on the current state of reefs than with your over generalization. I would suggest they are both scientists of the first order, they just happen to disagree on what the future holds for corals and the biodiversity they foster.

Auden,

Methane is often flared when it is not convenient to use so you are making greenhouse claims for use that should not be put against solar power generation. In other words, the mine has to clear the gas to make it safe to mine and it should be oxidizing it and not releasing it as a pollutant as a part of that process.

If you want to simply offset carbon emissions with solar, your best bet right now would be to build in the southwest where insolation is highest. And, that is where your cost comparison should be made.

In this case, the methane is convenient to use, at least for now. You should get credit for displacing the mix of emissions on your grid if you are underselling other gas generators, or perhaps coal use on your grid if there is a trend to close coal power plants there.

But, if your grid becomes renewable for the most part, your best bet might be to re-inject the methane if a good holding place could be found and the mine is still open. (Note that quite a few Appalachian power plants are burning western coal now and western mines may be the last to close aside from anthracite mines.)

Glad you are finding your solar array profitable.

Nick,

Obama's history with WV is interesting which is why I made that poke at him.

He should win the state just for having Joe Main do a thing or two for mine safety but more non-coal energy jobs such as silicon refining would have been nice to include in the stimulus. It would have been magnanimous.

I see you've finally acknowledged that there IS climate change.  It's great to see that you're making progress.  Hopefully the Al Gore-hating contingent will cede the fact that our carbon emissions are playing a part soon too.  Then we can have far more productive arguments about to solve the issue.

"Zombie ecology" means that my ideology demands that the reefs be dead, so they are dead. I don't care if they're still alive and growing and in peak health, I still say they're dead.

Why would coral reefs be dead at 2000ppm CO2? That was less than the atmospheric level when they evolved! Or do you hold that the Earth was created with 250ppm CO2 (no doubt 6000 years ago)?

Over the years the German government has published various studies which tried to predict the development in our energy mix. The real growth of renewables in our electricity mix is always beating those predictions. In 2010 the share of renewables was 16.8 percent, in 2011 already 20 percent, in the first half of 2012 it is 25 percent.

Even the most progressive and "green" technologies scenarios give by 2050 a heavy use of fossil fuels. These predictions and ways to deal with it are fully detailed by the independent International Energy Agency. It's worth to see what the real scenarios are, rather, like Mr Fox does, proposing only wishful thinking scenarios: http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/

Like Eddie I have also seen the accelerating deterioration of the coral reefs, around St. John.

I've also seen the exact parallel on the land. Trees are dying, all you have to do is look at them for obvious symptoms - bark splitting and oozing, bare branches, thin crowns, injured leaves and needles, holes, and cankers like cancerous tumors.

Ozone is well known to be even more toxic to plants than it is to people. How often have we heard that we should plant trees because they clean the air? And when does anyone ask what happens to the trees that absorb pollution through their foliage?

Roots are the first to go, even before visible damage is apparent, causing trees to fall on power lines and people. It make them even more susceptible to drought. Natural immunity to insects, disease and fungus is destroyed, all leading to wildfires.

Agricultural crops are diminished in yield and quality in the billions of dollars annually.

Like the coral reefs, trees are the foundation of their ecosystem. Consider the implications of a world without them and then let's decide just how important air travel and all other wasteful pollution-causing unnecessary activity really is to our survival.

There is a book for free download here: http://www.deadtrees-dyingforests.com/pillage-plunder-pollute-llc/

And a blog here: http://witsendnj.blogspot.com/

Corporations have done an even better job at hiding this information than the effects of smoking, acidifying oceans, and climate change.
